chicago.suntimes.com  (WEB - en-US)

The website for the Chicago Sun-Times, a daily Chicago newspaper.

This website generally maintains basic standards of credibility and transparency.
Does not repeatedly publish false content
Gathers and presents information responsibly
Regularly corrects or clarifies errors
Handles the difference between news and opinion responsibly
Avoids deceptive headlines
Website discloses ownership and financing
Clearly labels advertising
Reveals who's in charge, including any possible conflicts of interest
The site provides names of content creators, along with either contact or biographical information

Ownership and Financing

The website and the Chicago Sun-Times are operated by Sun-Times Media Group, which is owned by Edwin Eisendrath’s private investor group, SP Acquisition Holdings LLC. Eisendrath serves as the company’s CEO. Brands can advertise in the publication through marketing services offered by Sun-Times Media Group.

Content

Chicago.suntimes.com publishes articles related to local, national, and global news on business, politics, entertainment, the tech industry, food, and sports. It also features an obituaries section and an opinion section.

Chicago.suntimes.com hosts the site “31 Bullets,” an anti-gun violence initiative launched by the publication in April 2018 in response the Chicago’s crime problem. The page details 31 specific actions that readers can take to educate themselves on the issue of gun-control. For example, the first “bullet” features a discussion of guns in classrooms. The page opposes President Trump’s proposal to arm school teachers.  

Credibility

Chicago.suntimes.com articles are fact-based and typically cite multiple sources. The website distinguishes between news and opinion content from its editorial board and columnists. The site does not have a stated corrections policy, but corrections are appended as Editor’s Notes at the end of articles.

The newspaper’s editorial board has historically expressed a left-leaning perspective. In February 2007, the newspaper’s then editorial page manager announced that the board would focus on upholding the publication’s “liberal, working-class roots.”

In July 2017, a consortium of private investors and the Chicago Federation of Labor acquired Sun-Times Media Group, including the Chicago Sun-Times. The consortium was led by Edwin Eisendrath, a former Chicago alderman and an active Democratic. After the purchase, representatives of the Chicago Federation of Labor promised that despite the group’s party affiliation, the publication would remain independent when reporting on issues related to labor.

Transparency

The website’s Contact Us page provides contact information for the newspaper’s editor-in-chief, editorial page manager, deputy managing editor for news and sports, and SVP for digital news products. Articles name the writer, with link to the writer’s contact information.

Chicago.suntimes.com does not provide biographical information for its writers or staff. Two NewsGuard emails to Sun Times Editor-in-Chief Chris Fusco about the absence of information about the site’s content creators went unanswered.

Advertising content is marked as such.

History

The Chicago Sun-Times was founded in 1848 after the merger of the Chicago Sun and the Chicago Daily Times.
